sections.content: Here's a stat that might shock you: 56% of adults can't cover a $1,000 emergency expense without going into debt. This isn't about being bad with money — it's about not having a safety net. And that's exactly what we're going to build.
THE ANATOMY OF A FINANCIAL EMERGENCY

Financial emergencies aren't rare — they're inevitable. The washing machine breaks. The car needs new tyres. A kid gets sick and you need time off work. The question isn't IF an emergency will happen, it's WHEN.

Here's what makes them devastating: it's not the cost itself, it's the scramble. When you don't have savings, a $500 repair becomes a $500 repair PLUS $200 in credit card interest PLUS the stress of figuring out how to pay next month's bills.
The average family faces 3-4 financial 'surprises' per year. But here's the secret: if you plan for them, they stop being surprises. They become expected expenses that you've already saved for.

sections.prompt: Think about the last unexpected expense that stressed you out. What was it, and how much did it cost? This isn't to make you feel bad — it's to show you exactly what your emergency fund needs to cover.

sections.content: The good news? You don't need $10,000 in savings to feel secure. Research shows that even having $500 set aside dramatically reduces financial stress. That's our first target — a Starter Emergency Fund of $500.
Emergencies aren't surprises — they're certainties. The only question is whether you'll have money set aside when they arrive. Even $500 changes everything.
You've already mastered budgeting basics. Now we're adding the safety net that makes your whole financial plan bulletproof. Level 2 is where confidence really starts to build!
